analyzed: tasyām eva raghoḥ pāṇḍyāḥ pratāpam na viṣehire
translated: The Pandya kings could not bear the prowess of Raghu in that very land.

analyzed: tāmraparṇī sametasya muktā sāram mahā udadheḥ
translated: The Tamraparni river, along with the great ocean, gave him a necklace of pearls.

original: te nipatya dadustasmai yaśaḥ svamiva sañcitam // RaghK / //
analyzed: te nipatya daduḥ tasmai yaśaḥ svam iva sañcitam
translated: They fell down and gave him their accumulated fame, as if it were their own.

analyzed: sa nirviśya yathākāmam taṭa svādhīna candanau
translated: He enjoyed as he pleased the sandal trees on the banks, which were under his control.

original: stanāviva diśastasyāḥ śailau malayadurdurau // RaghK / //🔽asahyavikramaḥ sahyaṃ dūramuktamudanvatā /
analyzed: stanau iva diśaḥ tasyāḥ śailau malaya durdurau  asahya vikramaḥ sahyam dūram uktam udanvatā
translated: Like breasts, the mountains Malaya and Durdurdha were to the directions of that (river).🔽The ocean, which was unbearable in its prowess, left the Sahya mountain far away.

analyzed: nitambam iva medinyāḥ srasta aṃśukam alaṅghayat
translated: It crossed the Sahya mountain, as if it were the loosened garment of the earth.

analyzed: tasya anīkaiḥ visarpadbhiḥ aparānta jaya udyataiḥ
translated: With its armies spreading out, ready to conquer the southern regions,

analyzed: rāmeṣu utsāritaḥ pi āsīt sahya lagnaḥ iva arṇavaḥ
translated: the ocean seemed to be obstructed by the Sahya mountain, as if by the arrows of Rama.

analyzed: puras yat māruta uddhūtam agamat kaitakam rajaḥ
translated: When the pollen of the ketaki flowers, blown by the wind, went in front,

analyzed: tad yodha vāra vāṇānām ayatna paṭa vāsatām
translated: it became the effortless perfume for the mouths of the warriors.

original: abhyabhūyata vāhānāṃ rathānāṃ cāsya śiñjitaiḥ /🔽marmaraḥ pavanoddhūtarājatālīvanadhvaniḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: abhyabhūyata vāhānām rathānām ca asya śiñjitaiḥ  marmaraḥ pavana uddhūta rājatālī vana dhvaniḥ
translated: It was surpassed by the jingling of his horses and chariots,🔽the rustling sound of the royal palm forest, stirred by the wind.

analyzed: kharjūrī skandha naddhānām mada udgāra sugandhiṣu
translated: In the horses harnessed to the trunks of date palms, fragrant with the exhalation of their intoxication,

original: kaṭeṣu kariṇāṃ petuḥ punnāgebhyaḥ śilīmukhāḥ // RaghK / //🔽avakāśaṃ kilodanvānrāmāyābhyarthito dadau /
analyzed: kaṭeṣu kariṇām petuḥ punnāgebhyaḥ śilīmukhāḥ  avakāśam kila udanvān rāmāya abhyarthitaḥ dadau
translated: The arrows fell on the temples of elephants from the punnaga trees.🔽The ocean, it is said, granted space to Rama when requested,

analyzed: aparānta mahīpāla vyājena raghave karam
translated: under the pretext of the king of the southern region, Rama paid tribute to Raghu.

analyzed: mahā ibha radana utkīrṇa vyakta vikrama lakṣaṇam  trikūṭam eva tatra uccais jaya stambham cakāra saḥ
translated: The sign of his manifest valor was carved on the great elephant's tusk,🔽he made the Trikuta mountain itself a victory pillar there.

analyzed: pārasīkān tatas jetum pratasthe sthala vartmanā
translated: Then he set out to conquer the Persians by the land route,

original: indriyākhyāniva ripūṃstattvajñānena saṃyamī // RaghK / //🔽yavanīmukhapadmānāṃ sehe madhumadaṃ na saḥ /
analyzed: indriya ākhyān iva ripūn tattva jñānena saṃyamī  yavanī mukha padmānām sehe madhu madam na saḥ
translated: like one who restrains the enemies called senses by true knowledge.🔽He could not bear the honey intoxication of the lotuses in the faces of the Yavanas,

original: bālātapamivābjānāmakālajaladodayaḥ // RaghK / //🔽saṅgrāmastumulastasya pārasīkāśvasādhanaiḥ /🔽śārṅgakūjitavijñeyapratiyodho rajasyabhūt // RaghK / //🔽bhallāpavarjitaisteṣāṃ śirobhiḥ śmaśrulairmahīm /
analyzed: bāla ātapam iva abjānām akāla jalada udayaḥ  saṅgrāmaḥ tumulaḥ tasya pārasīka aśva sādhanaiḥ  śārṅga kūjita vijñeya pratiyodhaḥ rajasi abhūt  bhallāpa varjitaiḥ teṣām śirobhiḥ śmaśrulaiḥ mahīm
translated: like the untimely rise of clouds cannot bear the morning sun on the lotuses.🔽His tumultuous battle with the Persians, who used horses as their means of conveyance,🔽was recognized by the twang of his bow as his opponent in the dust.

analyzed: tastāra saraghā vyāptaiḥ sa kṣaudra paṭalaiḥ iva
translated: The earth was strewn with their headless trunks, with beards,🔽like a swarm of bees covered with pollen.

analyzed: apanīta śirastrāṇāḥ śeṣāḥ tam śaraṇam yayuḥ
translated: The remaining ones, their heads and armor removed, sought refuge in him.

analyzed: praṇipāta pratīkāraḥ saṃrambhaḥ hi mahātmanām
translated: For the anger of the great is the remedy for the humiliation of others.

analyzed: vinayante sma tad yodhāḥ madhubhiḥ vijaya śramam
translated: His warriors were refreshed by the honey,

analyzed: āstīrṇa ajina ratnāsu drākṣā valaya bhūmiṣu
translated: on the ground of Drakshavali, strewn with the gems of deer-skins.

analyzed: tatas pratasthe kauberīm bhāsvān iva raghuḥ diśam
translated: Then Raghu set out for the northern direction,

analyzed: śaraiḥ usraiḥ iva udīcyān uddhariṣyan rasān iva
translated: as if to draw up the northern juices with his arrows, as the sun does with his rays.

analyzed: jitān ajayyaḥ tān eva kṛtvā ratha puraḥsarān
translated: Making them, who were invincible to others, go in front of his chariot,

analyzed: mahā arṇavam iva aurva agniḥ praviveśa uttarāpatham  vinīta adhva śramāḥ tasya vaṅkṣu tīra viveṣṭanaiḥ
translated: he entered the northern path, like the submarine fire entering the great ocean.🔽His horses, their fatigue removed by the circling of the banks of the Vankshu,

original: dudhuvurvājinaḥ skandhāṃllagnakuṅkumakesarān // RaghK / //🔽tatra hūnāvarodhānāṃ bhartṛṣu vyaktavikramam /
analyzed: dudhuvuḥ vājinaḥ skandhān lagna kuṅkuma kesarān  tatra hūna avarodhānām bhartṛṣu vyakta vikramam
translated: shook their shoulders, on which the saffron was clinging.🔽There, Raghu's deeds became the teacher of cheek-biting among the husbands of the Huna women,

analyzed: kapola pāṭana ādeśi babhūva raghu ceṣṭitam
translated: his valour being manifest.

original: kāmbojāḥ samare vīryaṃ tasya soḍhumanīśvarāḥ /🔽gajālānaparikliṣṭairakṣoṭaiḥ sārdhamānatāḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: kāmbojāḥ samare vīryam tasya soḍhum anīśvarāḥ  gaja ālāna parikliṣṭaiḥ akṣoṭaiḥ sārdham ānatāḥ
translated: The Kambojas were unable to bear his valour in battle,🔽and were humbled along with the jujubes afflicted by the elephant's enclosure.

analyzed: teṣām sat aśva bhūyiṣṭhāḥ tuṅgāḥ draviṇa rāśayaḥ
translated: Their lofty heaps of wealth, consisting mostly of excellent horses,

original: viviśustaṃ viśāṃ nāthamudanvantamivāpagāḥ // RaghK / //🔽tato gaurīguruṃ śailamāruroha sasādhanaḥ /
analyzed: viviśuḥ tam viśām nātham udanvantam iva āpagāḥ  tatas gaurīgurum śailam āruroha sa sādhanaḥ
translated: entered him, O lord of the people, like rivers the ocean.🔽Then, with his army, he ascended the mountain, the preceptor of Gaurī,

analyzed: vardhayan iva tad kūṭān uddhataiḥ dhātu reṇubhiḥ  praśaṃsan tulya sattvānām sainya ghoṣe pi asambhramam
translated: as if increasing its peaks with the lofty dust of minerals.🔽Praising the fearless look of lions in caves, even in the midst of the noise of his army,

analyzed: guhā gatānām siṃhānām parivṛttyā avalokitam
translated: he, of equal courage, looked at the mountain peaks with his eyes.

analyzed: bhūrjeṣu marmarībhūtāḥ kīcaka dhvani hetavaḥ
translated: On the birch trees, the breezes, the cause of the sound of reeds,

original: gaṅgāśīkariṇo mārge marutastaṃ siṣevire // RaghK / //🔽viśaśramurnamerūṇāṃ chāyāsvadhyāsya sainikāḥ /🔽dṛṣado vāsitotsaṅgā niṣaṇṇamṛganābhibhiḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: gaṅgā śīkariṇaḥ mārge marutaḥ tam siṣevire  viśaśramuḥ namerūṇām chāyāsu adhyāsya sainikāḥ  dṛṣadaḥ vāsita utsaṅgāḥ niṣaṇṇa mṛga nābhibhiḥ
translated: moistened with the spray of the Ganges, served him on the path.🔽The soldiers rested in the shade of the snow-covered peaks,🔽sitting on rocks anointed with musk.

analyzed: sarala āsakta mātaṅga graiveya upacita tviṣaḥ
translated: The medicinal herbs, their luster increased by the necklaces of elephants attached to the sarala trees,

original: āsannoṣadhayo neturnaktamasnehadīpikāḥ // RaghK / //🔽tasyāvāseṣu dānārdrairgaṇḍabhittivighaṭṭanaiḥ /🔽gajavarṣma kirātebhyaḥ śaśaṃsurdevadāravaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: āsanna oṣadhayaḥ netuḥ naktam a sneha dīpikāḥ  tasya āvāseṣu dāna ārdraiḥ gaṇḍa bhitti vighaṭṭanaiḥ  gaja varṣma kirātebhyaḥ śaśaṃsuḥ devadāravaḥ
translated: were like lamps without oil to the king at night.🔽In his abodes, the devadāru trees, moistened with the gift of the splitting of their trunks by the elephants,🔽announced the presence of the Kirātas to the king.

analyzed: vimardaḥ saha taiḥ tatra pārvatīyaiḥ abhūt raghoḥ
translated: There was a conflict between Raghu and the mountaineers.

analyzed: śaraiḥ utsava saṅketān sa kṛtvā kara dān kṛtī
translated: And the fire that sprang up from the friction of the iron arrows shot by him.🔽Having made the Kinnaras pay tribute by the mere display of his prowess,

analyzed: jaya udāharaṇam bāhvoḥ gāpayāmāsa kinnarān
translated: he made them pay tribute to the arms that were the cause of his victory.

analyzed: parasparasya vijñātaḥ teṣu upāyana pāṇiṣu
translated: When they came with presents, he recognized each other,

original: rājñā himavataḥ sāro rājñaḥ sāro himādriṇā // RaghK / //
analyzed: rājñā himavataḥ sāraḥ rājñaḥ sāraḥ himādriṇā
translated: the essence of the Himalayas was the king, and the king was the essence of the Himalayas.

analyzed: tatra akṣobhyam yaśaḥ rāśim niveśya avaruroha saḥ
translated: There he descended, having placed his unshakable mass of fame,

original: paulastyatulitasyādrerādadāna iva hriyam // RaghK / //🔽cakampe tīrṇalauhitye tasminprāgjyotiṣeśvaraḥ /
analyzed: paulastya tulitasya adreḥ ādadānaḥ iva hriyam  cakampe tīrṇa lauhitye tasmin prāgjyotiṣa īśvaraḥ
translated: as if taking away the pride of the mountain weighed by Paulāstya.🔽When he had crossed the Lauhitya, the lord of Prāgjyotiṣa trembled,

analyzed: tad gajāla ānatām prāptaiḥ saha kālāguru drumaiḥ
translated: together with the black aloe wood trees that had become the tethering posts for his elephants.

analyzed: na prasehe sa ruddha arkam anabhra maya durdinam
translated: He could not bear the cloudless rainy season that obstructed the sun,

analyzed: ratha vaṃśa rajaḥ pi asya kutas eva patākinīm
translated: how much less his army with banners, even the dust of whose chariot wheel he could not bear.

analyzed: tam īśaḥ kāmarūpāṇām ati ākhaṇḍala vikramam
translated: The lord of Kāmarūpa, whose prowess surpassed that of Indra,

analyzed: bheje bhinna kaṭaiḥ nāgaiḥ anyān uparurodha yaiḥ
translated: he embraced, with whom he had obstructed others with his broken tusked elephants.

analyzed: kāmarūpa īśvaraḥ tasya hema pīṭha adhidevatām
translated: The lord of Kāmarūpa, the presiding deity of the golden throne of that (Indra),

analyzed: ratna puṣpa upahāreṇa chāyām ānarca pādayoḥ
translated: and with offerings of jeweled flowers, he worshipped the shade at his feet.

analyzed: iti jitvā diśaḥ jiṣṇuḥ nyavartata ratha uddhatam
translated: Thus, having conquered the directions, the victorious one returned,

analyzed: rajaḥ viśramayan rājñām chattra śūnyeṣu mauliṣu
translated: causing the dust raised by the chariot to rest on the crowns devoid of umbrellas of the kings.

analyzed: sa viśvajitam ājahre kratum sarva sva dakṣiṇam
translated: He performed the Vishvajit sacrifice, in which everything is given as a sacrificial fee,

original: ādānaṃ hi visargāya satāṃ vārimucāmiva // RaghK / //🔽sattrānte sacivasakhaḥ puraskriyābhirgurvībhiḥ śamitaparājayavyalīkān /
analyzed: ādānam hi visargāya satām vāri mucām iva  sattra ante saciva sakhaḥ puraskriyābhiḥ gurvībhiḥ śamita parājaya vyalīkān
translated: for the good, like clouds, give up for the sake of letting go.🔽At the end of the sacrifice, accompanied by his ministers, he pardoned the kings who had been defeated, their pride humbled by the heavy honors bestowed upon them,

original: kākutsthaściravirahotsukāvarodhān rājanyānsvapuranivṛttaye 'numene // RaghK / //🔽te rekhādhvajakalaśātapatracihnaṃ samrājaścaraṇayugaṃ prasādalabhyam /
analyzed: kākutsthaḥ cira viraha utsuka avarodhān rājanyān sva pura nivṛttaye numene  te rekhā dhvaja kalaśa atapatra cihnam samrājaḥ caraṇa yugam prasāda labhyam
translated: and Kakutstha allowed the kings, who had been eagerly awaiting his return for a long time, to return to their own cities.🔽They placed the two feet of the emperor, which were marked with lines, a flag, a pot, and an umbrella, and which were obtained through grace,

analyzed: prasthāna praṇatibhiḥ aṅgulīṣu cakruḥ mauli sraj cyuta makaranda reṇu gauram
translated: on their fingers by bowing down at the time of departure, making them pale like the pollen of lotuses fallen from the garlands on their heads.

analyzed: iti raghuvaṃśe mahākāvye caturthaḥ sargaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourth canto in the great poem called Raghuvamsa, composed by Kalidasa.

analyzed: tam adhvare viśvajiti kṣitīśam niḥśeṣa viśrāṇita kośa jātam
translated: That lord of the earth, who had given away all his wealth in the Vishvajit sacrifice,

original: upāttavidyo gurudakṣiṇārthī kautsaḥ prapede varatantuśiṣyaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: upātta vidyaḥ guru dakṣiṇā arthī kautsaḥ prapede vara tantu śiṣyaḥ
translated: Kautsa, the disciple of Varatantu, having acquired knowledge, and desirous of paying the guru-dakshina, approached him.

analyzed: sa mṛṇmaye vīta hiraṇmaya tvāt pātre nidhāya arghyam anargha śīlaḥ
translated: He, of priceless character, having placed the arghya in a clay vessel, due to the absence of a golden one,

original: śrutaprakāśaṃ yaśasā prakāśaḥ pratyujjagāmātithimātitheyaḥ // RaghK / //🔽tamarcayitvā vidhivadvidhijñastapodhanaṃ mānadhanāgrayāyī /🔽kṛtāñjaliḥ kṛtyavicāradakṣo viśāmpatirviṣṭarabhājamāha // RaghK / //
analyzed: śruta prakāśam yaśasā prakāśaḥ pratyujjagāma atithim ātitheyaḥ  tam arcayitvā vidhivat vidhi jñaḥ tapodhanam māna dhana agra yāyī  kṛtāñjaliḥ kṛtya vicāra dakṣaḥ viśām patiḥ viṣṭara bhājam āha
translated: the one worthy of hospitality, the one who illuminates through fame, received the guest who illuminates through learning.🔽Having duly worshipped the sage, the lord of the people, who was skilled in discerning what should be done, who was foremost in honoring the wealthy,🔽spoke to the one who deserved a seat, the one who knew the rules.

analyzed: api agraṇīḥ mantra kṛtām ṛṣīṇām kuśa agra buddhe kuśalī guruḥ te
translated: Is your guru, the foremost among the sages who composed the mantras, the one with a mind sharp as the tip of kusha grass, well?

analyzed: yatas tvayā jñānam aśeṣam āptam caitanyam ugrāt iva dīkṣitena
translated: From whom you have obtained complete knowledge, like consciousness from Ugra and others who have been initiated.

original: kāyena vācā manasā ca taptaṃ yadvajriṇo dhairyaviparyayāya /
analyzed: kāyena vācā manasā ca taptam yat vajriṇaḥ dhairya viparyayāya
translated: The austerity performed by the wielder of the thunderbolt, with body, speech, and mind, to test his fortitude,

original: āpādyate na vyayamantarāyaiḥ kaccinmaharṣestrividhaṃ tapastat // RaghK / //
analyzed: āpādyate na vyayam antarāyaiḥ kaccit mahā ṛṣeḥ trividham tapaḥ tat
translated: is that threefold austerity of the great sage not being diminished by obstacles?

analyzed: ādhāra bandha pramukhaiḥ prayatnaiḥ saṃvardhitānām suta nirviśeṣam
translated: Of those who are nurtured by efforts such as the binding of the base, like sons,

original: kaccinna vāyvādirupaplavo vaḥ śramacchidāmāśramapādapānām // RaghK / //🔽kriyānimitteṣvapi vatsalatvādabhagnakāmā munibhiḥ kuśeṣu /
analyzed: kaccit na vāyu ādiḥ upaplavaḥ vaḥ śrama chidām āśrama pādapānām  kriyā nimitteṣu api vatsala tvāt abhagna kāmā munibhiḥ kuśeṣu
translated: I hope the trees in your hermitage, which dispel fatigue, have not been damaged by storms or other calamities.🔽Even in matters of ritual, the sages, out of affection, do not break their desire for the kusha grass.

analyzed: tad aṅka śayyā acyuta nābhi nālā kaccit mṛgīṇām anaghā prasūtiḥ
translated: I hope the birth of the does, which fell from the navel-string of Vishnu lying on their laps, is faultless.

analyzed: nirvartyate yaiḥ niyama abhiṣekaḥ yatas nivāpa añjalayaḥ pitṛṇām
translated: By whom the consecration of rituals is performed, from whom the libations of water are offered to the ancestors,

original: tānyuñchaṣaṣṭhāṅkitasaikatāni śivāni vastīrthajalāni kaccit // RaghK / //🔽nīvārapākādi kaḍaṅgarīyairāmṛṣyate jānapadairna kaccit /
analyzed: tāni uñcha ṣaṣṭha aṅkita saikatāni śivāni vaḥ tīrtha jalāni kaccit  nīvāra pāka ādi kaḍaṅgarīyaiḥ āmṛṣyate jānapadaiḥ na kaccit
translated: I hope those auspicious waters of holy places, marked by the sixth part of the alms, are safe.

analyzed: kāla upapanna atithi bhāgadheyam vanyam śarīra sthiti sādhanam vaḥ
translated: I hope the forest people do not appropriate the nīvāra rice and other things, which are the means of sustenance for your bodies, the share of guests who arrive at the proper time.

original: api prasannena maharṣiṇā tvaṃ samyagvinīyānumato gṛhāya /
analyzed: api prasannena mahā ṛṣiṇā tvam samyak vinīya anumataḥ gṛhāya
translated: Even though you have been properly instructed and permitted by the pleased great sage to return home,

original: kālo hyayaṃ saṅkramituṃ dvitīyaṃ sarvopakārakṣamamāśramaṃ te // RaghK / //
analyzed: kālaḥ hi ayam saṅkramitum dvitīyam sarva upakāra kṣamam āśramam te
translated: this is the time for you to enter the second hermitage, which is capable of rendering all help.

original: tavārhato nābhigamena tṛptaṃ mano niyogakriyayotsukaṃ me /
analyzed: tava arhataḥ na abhigamena tṛptam manaḥ niyoga kriyayā utsukam me
translated: My mind, which is not satisfied by your arrival, is eager for the performance of the duties of appointment.

original: apyājñayā śāsiturātmanā vā prāpto 'si sambhāvayituṃ vanānmām // RaghK / //
analyzed: api ājñayā śāsituḥ ātmanā vā prāptaḥ si sambhāvayitum vanāt mām
translated: Even by the command of the king or by your own will, you have come to honour me in the forest.

analyzed: iti arghya pātra anumita vyayasya raghoḥ udārām api gām niśamya
translated: Thus, having heard the generous words of Raghu, inferred from the Arghya vessel,

original: svārthopapattiṃ prati durbalāśaḥ pratyāha kautsastamapetakutsam // RaghK / //
analyzed: sva artha upapattim prati durbala āśaḥ pratyāha kautsaḥ tam apeta kutsam
translated: Kautsa, whose desire was weak in obtaining his own purpose, replied to him, who was free from contempt.

original: sarvatra no vārttamavaihi rājannāthe kutastvayyaśubhaṃ prajānām /
analyzed: sarvatra naḥ vārttam avaihi rājan nāthe kutas tvayi aśubham prajānām
translated: Know everywhere, O king, that there is no harm to the people in you, the protector.

original: sūrye tapatyāvaraṇāya dṛṣṭeḥ kalpeta lokasya kathaṃ tamisrā // RaghK / //
analyzed: sūrye tapati āvaraṇāya dṛṣṭeḥ kalpeta lokasya katham tamisrā
translated: When the sun is seen to shine, how can darkness be imagined for the world?

analyzed: bhaktiḥ pratīkṣyeṣu kula ucitā te pūrvān mahābhāga tayā atiśeṣe
translated: Your devotion to those who are to be waited upon is proper to your family, and it excels by your great fortune.

original: vyapetakālastvahamabhyupetastvāmarthibhāvāditi me viṣādaḥ // RaghK / //🔽śarīramātreṇa narendra tiṣṭhannābhāsi tīrthapratipāditarddhiḥ /🔽āraṇyakopāttaphalaprasūtiḥ stambena nīvāra ivāvaśiṣṭaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: vyapeta kālaḥ tu aham abhyupetaḥ tvām arthi bhāvāt iti me viṣādaḥ  śarīra mātreṇa narendra tiṣṭhan ābhāsi tīrtha pratipādita ṛddhiḥ  āraṇyaka upātta phala prasūtiḥ stambena nīvāraḥ iva avaśiṣṭaḥ
translated: I am come to you at the proper time, as a supplicant; this is my sorrow.🔽O lord of men, standing with only your body, you do not appear to have the prosperity bestowed by the sacred places.🔽You remain like a stump of wild rice, with the fruit of wild rice obtained, left over.

original: sthāne bhavānekanarādhipaḥ san akiñcanatvaṃ makhajaṃ vyanakti /
analyzed: sthāne bhavān eka narādhipaḥ san akiñcana tvam makha jam vyanakti
translated: In a proper place, you, being a king of men, declare your poverty born from the sacrifice.

original: paryāyapītasya surairhimāṃśoḥ kalākṣayaḥ ślāghyataro hi vṛddheḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: paryāya pītasya suraiḥ himāṃśoḥ kalā kṣayaḥ ślāghyataraḥ hi vṛddheḥ
translated: For the waning of the digit of the moon drunk by the gods in turn is more praiseworthy than its waxing.

analyzed: tat anyatas tāvat ananya kāryaḥ guru artham āhartum aham yatiṣye
translated: I shall therefore strive to obtain wealth for my preceptor, for which I have no other use.

original: svastyastu te nirgalitāmbugarbhaṃ śaradghanaṃ nārdati cātako 'pi // RaghK / //
analyzed: svasti astu te nirgalita ambu garbham śarad ghanam na ardati
translated: May you fare well! Even the ruddy goose is not distressed at the autumn cloud, which has vomited forth its water-filled belly.

analyzed: etāvat uktvā pratiyātu kāmam śiṣyam mahā ṛṣeḥ nṛpatiḥ niṣidhya
translated: When the disciple, having said this much, was about to depart, the king, stopping the great sage,

original: kiṃ vastu vidvangurave pradeyaṃ tvayā kiyadveti tamanvayuṅkta // RaghK / //
analyzed: kim vastu vidvan gurave pradeyam tvayā kiyat vā iti tam anvayuṅkta
translated: asked him, What object, O learned one, should be given to the preceptor by you, and how much?

analyzed: tatas yathāvat vihita adhvarāya tasmai smaya āveśa vivarjitāya
translated: Then to him, who had duly performed the sacrifice, who was free from the influence of pride,

original: varṇāśramāṇāṃ gurave sa varṇī vicakṣaṇaḥ prastutamācacakṣe // RaghK / //
analyzed: varṇa āśramāṇām gurave sa varṇī vicakṣaṇaḥ prastutam ācacakṣe
translated: the wise one, belonging to the Varna, spoke of the present matter to the preceptor of the Varnas and Ashramas.

analyzed: avāpta vidyena mayā mahā ṛṣiḥ vijñāpitaḥ bhūt guru dakṣiṇāyai
translated: When I had obtained knowledge, I informed the great sage of my desire to give a guru-dakshina.

original: sa me cirādaskhalitopacārāṃ tāṃ bhaktimevāgaṇayatpurastāt // RaghK / //
analyzed: sa me cirāt askhalita upacārām tām bhaktim evā agaṇayat purastāt
translated: He, in front of me, considered that very devotion, which had been unswerving for a long time, as the dakshina.

analyzed: nirbandha sañjāta ruṣā atha kārśyam a cintayitvā guruṇā aham uktaḥ
translated: Then, being angry at the insistence, I, disregarding the emaciation, was told by the preceptor,

original: vittasya vidyāparisaṅkhyayā me koṭīścatasro daśa cāhareti // RaghK / //
analyzed: vittasya vidyā parisaṅkhyayā me koṭīḥ catasraḥ daśa ca āhara iti
translated: I have four and ten crores of wealth, which is limited by my learning.

analyzed: saḥ ham saparyā vidhi bhājanena matvā bhavantam prabhu śabda śeṣam
translated: I, considering you to be the remainder of the word 'lord' by the vessel of the rite of worship,

analyzed: abhyutsahe samprati nā uparoddhum alpa itara tvāt śruta niṣkrayasya
translated: I dare not withhold now, because of the price of learning being not less than that.

analyzed: ittham dvijena dvijarāja kāntiḥ āveditaḥ veda vidām vareṇa
translated: Thus, the one dear to the king of the twice-born, was informed by the best among the knowers of the Vedas,

original: enonivṛttendriyavṛttirenaṃ jagāda bhūyo jagadekanāthaḥ // RaghK / //🔽gurvarthamarthī śrutapāradṛśvā raghoḥ sakāśādanavāptakāmaḥ /
analyzed: enaḥ nivṛtta indriya vṛttiḥ enam jagāda bhūyas jagadekanāthaḥ  guru artham arthī śruta pāra dṛśvā raghoḥ sakāśāt anavāpta kāmaḥ
translated: The one whose senses and activities were withdrawn, the sole lord of the world, spoke to him again.🔽Desiring wealth for the sake of the guru, having mastered the Vedas, not having obtained my desire from Raghu,

original: gato vadanyāntaramityayaṃ me mā bhūtparīvādanavāvatāraḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: gataḥ vadanya antaram iti ayam me mā
translated: Let this not be a new beginning of slander for me that I have gone to another.

original: sa tvaṃ prayaste mahito madīye vasaṃścaturtho 'gnirivāgnyagāre /
analyzed: sa tvam prayas te mahitaḥ madīye vasan caturthaḥ gniḥ iva agnyagāre
translated: Therefore, you, being worshipped by me, dwelling like the fourth fire in the fire-house,

analyzed: dvitrāṇi ahāni arhasi soḍhum arhan yāvadyate sādhayitum tvad artham
translated: You are worthy to bear two or three days, until what is to be done for you is accomplished.

analyzed: tathā iti tasya avitatham pratītaḥ pratyagrahīt saṅgaram agrya janmā
translated: Saying 'So be it', he, the first-born, being convinced of his truthful words, accepted the agreement.

original: gāmāttasārāṃ raghurapyavekṣya niṣkraṣṭumarthaṃ cakame kuverāt // RaghK / //🔽vasiṣṭhamantrokṣaṇajātprabhāvādudanvadākāśamahīdhareṣu /
analyzed: gām ātta sārām raghuḥ api avekṣya niṣkraṣṭum artham cakame kuverāt  vasiṣṭha mantra ukṣaṇa jāt prabhāvāt udanvat ākāśa mahīdhareṣu
translated: Raghn also, beholding the earth shorn of her essence, desired to extract wealth from Kubera.🔽By the power of the consecration with the mantras of Vasishtha, the course of his chariot was not obstructed in the ocean, sky, or mountain regions,

original: marutsakhasyeva balāhakasya gatirvijaghne na hi tadrathasya // RaghK / //
analyzed: marut sakhasya iva balāhakasya gatiḥ vijaghne na hi tat rathasya
translated: like that of the cloud accompanied by the Maruts.

original: athādhiśiśye prayataḥ pradoṣe rathaṃ raghuḥ kalpitamastragarbham /
analyzed: athā adhiśiśye prayataḥ pradoṣe ratham raghuḥ kalpitam astra garbham
translated: Then, in the evening, Raghn, with concentrated mind, mounted the chariot, which was fitted with weapons within,

original: sāmantasambhāvanayaiva dhīraḥ kailāsanāthaṃ tarasā jigīṣuḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: sāmanta sambhāvanayā eva dhīraḥ kailāsa nātham tarasā jigīṣuḥ
translated: the resolute one, desiring to conquer the lord of Kailasa quickly, by the mere respect of the neighboring kings.

original: prātaḥ prayāṇābhimukhāya tasmai savismayāgantumudo niyuktāḥ /🔽hiraṇmayīṃ kośagṛhasya madhye vṛṣṭiṃ śaśaṃsuḥ patitāṃ nabhastaḥ // RaghK / //🔽taṃ bhūpatirbhāsvarahemarāśiṃ labdhaṃ kuverādabhiyāsyamānāt /
analyzed: prātar prayāṇa abhimukhāya tasmai sa vismaya āgantu mudaḥ niyuktāḥ  hiraṇmayīm kośagṛhasya madhye vṛṣṭim śaśaṃsuḥ patitām nabhastaḥ  tam bhūpatiḥ bhāsvara hema rāśim labdham kuverāt abhiyāsyamānāt
translated: To him, who was facing the morning journey, the messengers, filled with wonder,🔽announced the rain of gold fallen from the sky in the middle of the treasury house.🔽The king ordered the entire quarter to be given to Kautsa,

original: dideśa kautsāya samagrameva pādaṃ sumeroriva vajrabhinnam // RaghK / //
analyzed: dideśa kautsāya samagram eva pādam sumeroḥ iva vajra bhinnam
translated: which was obtained from Kubera, who was approaching, like the peak of Mount Meru cleft by the thunderbolt.

analyzed: janasya sāketa nivāsinaḥ tau dvau api abhūtām abhinandya sattvau
translated: Both of them became greatly liked by the people residing in Saketa,

original: gurupradeyādhikaniḥspṛho 'rthī nṛpo 'rthikāmādadhikapradaśca // RaghK / //🔽athoṣṭravāmīśatahāritārthaṃ prajeśvaraṃ prītamanā manīṣī /
analyzed: guru pradeya adhika niḥspṛhaḥ rthī nṛpaḥ rthi kāmāt adhika pradaḥ ca  atha uṣṭra vāmī śata hārita artham prajā īśvaram prīta manāḥ manīṣī
translated: The king, who was indifferent to the wealth that was to be given to his preceptor, and the supplicant, who was more generous in giving than the king in desiring wealth.

analyzed: spṛśan kareṇa ānata pūrva kāyam samprasthitaḥ vākyam uvāca kautsaḥ
translated: Then the wise Kautsa, with a delighted mind, touched the king, the lord of the people, who had brought the wealth carried by the camel and the mare, on the back that was bent, and set out, speaking these words:

analyzed: kim atra citram yadi kāma sūḥ bhūḥ vṛtta sthitasya adhipateḥ prajānām
translated: What is wonderful here if the earth grants desires to a king who is established in good conduct?

original: acintanīyastava tu prabhāvo manīṣitaṃ dyaurapi yena dugdhā // RaghK / //
analyzed: a cintanīyaḥ tava tu prabhāvaḥ manīṣitam dyauḥ api yena dugdhā
translated: But your power is inconceivable, by whom even the sky, which is desired, was milked.

analyzed: āśāsyam anyat punar ukta bhūtam śreyāṃsi sarvāṇi adhijagmuṣaḥ te
translated: Another blessing is redundant for you, who have obtained all the best things.

original: putraṃ labhasvātmaguṇānurūpaṃ bhavantamīḍyo bhavataḥ piteva // RaghK / //
analyzed: putram labhasva ātma guṇa anurūpam bhavantam īḍyaḥ bhavataḥ pitā iva
translated: Obtain a son who is like your own qualities, who is to be praised by you, just like your father.

original: itthaṃ prayujyāśiṣamagryajanmā rājñe pratīyāya guroḥ sakāśam /
analyzed: ittham prayujya āśiṣam agrya janmā rājñe pratīyāya guroḥ sakāśam
translated: Having thus offered a blessing, the eldest-born Kautsa went to his preceptor, from the king.

original: rājāpi lebhe sutamāśu tasmād ālokamarkādiva jīvalokaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: rājā api lebhe sutam āśu tasmāt ālokam arkāt iva jīvalokaḥ
translated: And the king quickly obtained a son from him, like the world of living beings obtains light from the sun.

original: brāhme muhūrte kila tasya devī kumārakalpaṃ suṣuve kumāram /
analyzed: brāhme muhūrte kila tasya devī kumāra kalpam suṣuve kumāram
translated: In the Brahma muhurta, it is said, the queen gave birth to a prince, who was like Kumara (Skanda), the son of Shiva.

original: ataḥ pitā brahmaṇa eva nāmnā tamagryajanmānamajaṃ cakāra // RaghK / //
analyzed: atas pitā brahmaṇaḥ eva nāmnā tam agrya janmānam ajam cakāra
translated: Therefore, the father named him Brahma's eldest son, the unborn one.

original: rūpaṃ tadojasvi tadeva vīryaṃ tadeva naisargikamunnatatvam /
analyzed: rūpam tat ojasvi tat eva vīryam tat eva naisargikam unnata tvam
translated: That form is full of vigor, that is the same valor, that is the same natural loftiness.

original: na kāraṇātsvādbibhide kumāraḥ pravartito dīpa iva pradīpāt // RaghK / //🔽upāttavidyaṃ vidhivadgurubhyastaṃ yauvanodbhedaviśeṣakāntam /
analyzed: na kāraṇāt svāt bibhide kumāraḥ pravartitaḥ dīpaḥ iva pradīpāt  upātta vidyam vidhivat gurubhyaḥ tam yauvana udbheda viśeṣa kāntam
translated: The prince did not differ from his cause, like a lamp lit from another lamp.🔽Having received his education duly from his preceptors, he, whose beauty was enhanced by the onset of youth,

original: śrīḥ kāmayānāpi guroranujñāṃ dhīreva kanyā piturācakāṅkṣa // RaghK / //
analyzed: śrīḥ kāmayānā api guroḥ anujñām dhīrā iva kanyā pituḥ ācakāṅkṣa
translated: The goddess of wealth, though desirous, awaited the permission of her lord, like a maiden of her father's consent.

analyzed: atha īśvareṇa kratha kaiśikānām svayaṃvara artham svasuḥ indumatyāḥ
translated: Then, the king of the Krathakaishikas, eager to bring the prince for the svayamvara of his sister Indumati,

original: āptaḥ kumārānayanotsukena bhojena dūto raghave visṛṣṭaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: āptaḥ kumāra ānayana utsukena bhojena dūtaḥ raghave visṛṣṭaḥ
translated: Sent a messenger to Raghu, who was released by Bhoja.

original: taṃ ślāghyasambandhamasau vicintya dārakriyāyogyadaśaṃ ca putram /
analyzed: tam ślāghya sambandham asau vicintya dārakriyā yogya daśam ca putram
translated: He, considering that alliance worthy of praise and his son fit for marriage,

analyzed: prasthāpayāmāsa sa sainyam enam ṛddhām vidarbha adhipa rājadhānīm
translated: Sent him with his army to the prosperous capital of the king of Vidarbha.

analyzed: tasya upakāryā a racita upakārāḥ vandhyā itarāḥ jānapada upadhābhiḥ
translated: The people of the country, who had received favors from him and returned them, were disappointed by the other means of livelihood.

analyzed: mārge nivāsāḥ manuja indra sūnoḥ babhūvuḥ udyāna vihāra kalpāḥ
translated: The halting places on the way of the son of the lord of men were like pleasure gardens.

analyzed: sa narmadā rodhasi śīkara ārdraiḥ marudbhiḥ ānartita ketumāle
translated: On the banks of the Narmada, with the garlands of his banners shaken by the wind-borne sprays,

original: niveśayāmāsa vilaṅghitādhvā senāṃ śramotphenavanāyujāśvām // RaghK / //🔽athopariṣṭādbhramarairbhramadbhiḥ prāksūcitāntaḥsalilapraveśaḥ /
analyzed: niveśayāmāsa vilaṅghita adhvā senām śrama utphena vanāyu ja aśvām  atha upariṣṭāt bhramaraiḥ bhramadbhiḥ prāc sūcita antar salila praveśaḥ
translated: he encamped his army, the horses of which were covered with foam from the exertion of the journey,🔽Then, from above, a wild elephant, previously indicated by the hovering bees, entered the water,

original: nirdhautadānāmalagaṇḍabhittirvanyaḥ saritto gaja unmamajja // RaghK / //🔽apyaughavikṣālitagairikeṇa vaprakriyāmṛkṣavatastaṭeṣu /
analyzed: nirdhauta dāna amalagaṇḍa bhittiḥ vanyaḥ sarittaḥ gajaḥ unmamajja  api augha vikṣālita gairikeṇa vapra kriyām ṛkṣavataḥ taṭeṣu
translated: with his cheeks washed clean by the water, his tusks free from mud.🔽On the banks of the Himalayas, with his two tusks, white like powdered chalk,

original: nīlordhvalekhāśavalena śaṃsandantadvayenāśmavikuṇṭhitena // RaghK / //🔽saṃhāravikṣepalaghukriyeṇa hastena tīrābhimukhaḥ saśabdam /
analyzed: nīla ūrdhva lekhā śavalena śaṃsan danta dvayena aśma vikuṇṭhitena  saṃhāra vikṣepa laghu kriyeṇa hastena tīra abhimukhaḥ sa śabdam
translated: showing the path made by the current, which had washed away the red chalk,🔽with his trunk, which was capable of quick movements of contraction and expansion, he suddenly broke through the waves,

original: babhau sa bhindansahasā taraṅgānvāryargalābhaṅga iva pravṛttaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: babhau sa bhindan sahasā taraṅgān vāri argala ābhaṅgaḥ iva pravṛttaḥ
translated: as if beginning to break the dam of the sea, facing the bank with a sound.

analyzed: kāraṇḍava ucchiṣṭa mṛdu pratānāḥ pulinda yoṣā ambu vihāra kāñcīḥ
translated: The women of the Pulinda tribe, with their girdles of lotus stalks,

analyzed: karṣan sa śevāla latāḥ nadīṣṇaḥ proha avalagnāḥ taṭam utsasarpa
translated: Drawing up the creepers of moss, the elephant, with its rutting fluid clinging to the branches, moved towards the bank.

analyzed: tasya eka nāgasya kapola bhittyoḥ hrada avagāha kṣaṇa mātra śāntā
translated: The ichor on the temples of that single elephant, which had subsided for a moment on entering the lake,

original: vanyetarānekapadarśanena punardidīpe madadurdinaśrīḥ // RaghK / //🔽saptacchadakṣīrakaṭupravāhamasahyamāghrāya madaṃ tadīyam /
analyzed: vanya itara an eka pada rśanena punar didīpe mada durdina śrīḥ  saptacchada kṣīra kaṭu pravāham asahyam āghrāya madam tadīyam
translated: again shone forth on seeing the many other wild elephants, with the splendor of a rainy day of passion.🔽The great elephants of the army, unable to bear the unbearable ichor, flowing with the pungent smell of saptala sap,

original: vilaṅghitādhoraṇatīvrayatnāḥ senāgajendrā vimukhā babhūvuḥ // RaghK / //🔽sa cchinnabandhadrutayugyaśūnyaṃ bhagnākṣaparyastarathaṃ kṣaṇena /
analyzed: vilaṅghita ādhoraṇa tīvra yatnāḥ senā gaja indrāḥ vimukhāḥ babhūvuḥ  sa chinna bandha druta yugya śūnyam bhagna akṣa paryasta ratham kṣaṇena
translated: with their efforts to control the reins greatly surpassed, turned their faces away.

analyzed: rāmā paritrāṇa vihasta yodham senā niveśam tumulam cakāra
translated: He, in a moment, made the army camp tumultuous, with the yokes of the hastily unyoked carriages empty, the axles of the chariots broken and overturned, and the warriors distracted by the lack of Rama's protection.

original: tamāpatantaṃ nṛpateravadhyo vanyaḥ karīti śrutavānkumāraḥ /🔽nivartayiṣyanviśikhena kumbhe jaghāna nātyāyatakṛṣṭaśārṅgaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: tam āpatantam nṛpateḥ avadhyaḥ vanyaḥ karī iti śrutavān kumāraḥ  nivartayiṣyan viśikhena kumbhe jaghāna na ati āyata kṛṣṭa śārṅgaḥ
translated: The prince, who had heard that the wild elephant was unassailable by the king,🔽with his bow drawn not too far, struck him on the forehead with an arrow, intending to turn him back.

analyzed: sa viddha mātraḥ kila nāga rūpam utsṛjya tad vismita sainya dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: As soon as he was pierced, he is said to have abandoned his elephant form, while the astonished soldiers looked on,

analyzed: sphurat prabhā maṇḍala madhya varti kāntam vapuḥ vyoma caram prapede
translated: And assumed a charming form, shining in the midst of a halo of light, and moving in the sky.

analyzed: atha prabhāva upanataiḥ kumāram kalpadruma utthaiḥ avakīrya puṣpaiḥ
translated: Then, having strewn the prince with flowers sprung from the wish-fulfilling tree, which had come to him through his power,

analyzed: uvāca vāgmī daśana prabhābhiḥ saṃvardhita uraḥsthala tāra hāraḥ
translated: The eloquent one, with his necklace of pearls on his broad chest enhanced by the lustre of his teeth, spoke.

analyzed: mataṅga śāpāt avalepa mūlāt avāptavān asmi mataṅga ja tvam
translated: I have attained the state of an elephant due to my arrogance, which is the root of the curse of Matanga.

original: avaihi gandharvapatestanūjaṃ priyaṃvadaṃ māṃ priyadarśanasya // RaghK / //
analyzed: avaihi gandharva pateḥ tanūjam priyaṃvadam mām priya darśanasya
translated: Know me to be Priyavada, the son of Priyadarśana, the son of the lord of the Gandharvas.

analyzed: sa ca anunītaḥ praṇatena paścāt mayā mahā ṛṣiḥ mṛdu tām agacchat
translated: And that great sage, when entreated and bowed to by me afterwards, became mild.

original: uṣṇatvamagnyātapasamprayogācchaityaṃ hi yatsā prakṛtirjalasya // RaghK / //🔽ikṣvākuvaṃśaprabhavo yadā te bhetsyatyajaḥ kumbhamayomukhena /
analyzed: uṣṇa tvam agni ātapa samprayogāt śaityam hi yat sā prakṛtiḥ jalasya  ikṣvāku vaṃśa prabhavaḥ yadā te bhetsyati ajaḥ kumbham ayomukhena
translated: For the nature of water is coldness, which it attains by contact with fire or the sun, just as heat.

original: saṃyokṣyase svena punarmahimnā tadetyavocatsa taponidhirmām // RaghK / //
analyzed: saṃyokṣyase svena punar mahimnā tadā iti avocat sa taponidhiḥ mām
translated: When Aja, born in the Ikshvaku dynasty, will break your pot with his arrow, then you will be united with your own greatness again, thus spoke that treasure of austerities to me.

original: sa mocitaḥ śāpakalestvayāhaṃ gatiṃ prapanno vihitāṃ vidhātrā /
analyzed: sa mocitaḥ śāpa kaleḥ tvayā aham gatim prapannaḥ vihitām vidhātrā
translated: By you, I have been released from the noose of the curse, and have attained the state ordained by the Creator.

original: pratikriyāṃ cedbhavato na kuryāṃ vyarthā hi me syātsvapadopalabdhiḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: pratikriyām ced bhavataḥ na kuryām vyarthā hi me syāt sva pada upalabdhiḥ
translated: If I do not retaliate, then my very existence would be futile.

analyzed: gāndharvam astram tat itas pratīccha prayoga saṃhāra vibhakta mantram
translated: Accept from me this weapon called Gandharva, with its mantras for invocation and dismissal.

original: prasvāpanaṃ nāma yataḥ praharturna cārihiṃsā vijayaśca haste // RaghK / //
analyzed: prasvāpanam nāma yatas prahartuḥ na ca ari hiṃsā vijayaḥ ca haste
translated: From it, you can use the weapon called Prasvapana, which does not harm the enemy, but brings victory.

original: alaṃ hriyā māṃ prati yanmuhūrtaṃ dayāparo 'bhūḥ praharannapi tvam /
analyzed: alam hriyāḥ mām prati yat muhūrtam dayā paraḥ bhūḥ praharan api tvam
translated: Do not be ashamed before me, for even as you struck me, you were full of compassion for a moment.

original: tasmādupacchandayati prayojyaṃ mayi tvayā na pratiṣedharaukṣyam // RaghK / //🔽tathetyupaspṛśya payaḥ pavitraṃ somodbhavāyāḥ sarito nṛsomaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt upacchandayati prayojyam mayi tvayā na pratiṣedha raukṣyam  tathā iti upaspṛśya payaḥ pavitram soma udbhavāyāḥ saritaḥ nṛsomaḥ
translated: Therefore, I request you, do not be harsh with prohibitions towards me.🔽Saying So be it, the moon among men, having touched the sacred water of the river born from Soma,

analyzed: udak mukhaḥ saḥ stra vid astra mantram jagrāha tasmāt vigṛhīta śāsī
translated: faced north and received the weapon mantra from him, the one who had taken up arms.

analyzed: evam tayoḥ adhvani daiva yogāt āseduṣoḥ sakhyam acintya hetu
translated: Thus, by chance, the friendship of those two, whose cause was inconceivable, arose on the road.

analyzed: ekaḥ yayau caitraratha pradeśān saurājya ramyān aparaḥ vidarbhān
translated: One went to the regions of Chaitraratha, the other to the Vidarbha country, delightful due to good governance.

analyzed: tam tasthivāṃsam nagara upakaṇṭhe tad āgama ārūḍha guru praharṣaḥ
translated: He, having stayed near the city, with great joy arisen from his arrival,

analyzed: pratyujjagāma kratha kaiśika indraḥ candram pravṛddha ūrmiḥ iva ūrmimālī
translated: And the lord of the Krathakaishikas (the king of the Kasis) came out to receive him, like a sea with its line of waves rising in eagerness to meet the moon.

analyzed: praveśya ca enam puram agra yāyī nīcaiḥ tathā upācarat arpita śrīḥ
translated: And the king, the first to go out, having brought him into the city, served him with lowliness, his pride being humbled.

original: mene yathā tatra janaḥ sameto vaidarbhamāgantumajaṃ gṛheśam // RaghK / //🔽tasyādhikāripuruṣaiḥ praṇataiḥ pradiṣṭāṃ prāgdvāravediviniveśitahemakumbhām /
analyzed: mene yathā tatra janaḥ sametaḥ vaidarbham āgantum ajam gṛheśam  tasya adhikāri puruṣaiḥ praṇataiḥ pradiṣṭām prāc dvāra vedi viniveśita hema kumbhām
translated: So that the people assembled there thought that the lord of the house, the son of Vidarbha, had come to visit Ajā.🔽The son of Raghu, the representative of Raghu, occupied a charming new place of honour, indicated by the bowing attendants, where golden pitchers were placed on the altar of the eastern gate,

original: ramyāṃ raghupratinidhiḥ sa navopakāryāṃ bālyātparāmiva daśāṃ madano 'dhitasthau // RaghK / //🔽tatra svayaṃvarasamāhṛtarājalokaṃ kanyālalāma kamanīyamajasya lipsoḥ /
analyzed: ramyām raghu pratinidhiḥ sa nava upakāryām bālyāt parām iva daśām madanaḥ dhitasthau  tatra svayaṃvara samāhṛta rāja lokam kanyā lalāma kamanīyam ajasya lipsoḥ
translated: as if it were a stage of life superior to that of childhood, to be served by him.🔽There, as he was desirous of obtaining the beautiful maiden, the crest-jewel of all maidens, in the assembly of kings gathered for the svayamvara,

original: bhāvāvabodhakaluṣā dayiteva rātrau nidrā cireṇa nayanābhimukhī babhūva // RaghK / //
analyzed: bhāva avabodha kaluṣā dayitā iva rātrau nidrā cireṇa nayana abhimukhī babhūva
translated: sleep, as if it were his beloved, long delayed in appearing before his eyes, being troubled by the thought of his feelings.

analyzed: tam karṇabhūṣaṇa nipīḍita pīvara aṃsam śayyā uttaracchada vimarda kṛśa aṅgarāgam
translated: His broad shoulders pressed by the earrings, the unguent on his limbs thinned by the rubbing against the upper sheet of the bed,

analyzed: vaitālikāḥ lalita bandha manoharābhiḥ prābodhayan uṣasi vāgbhiḥ uṣarbudha ābham
translated: the bards awakened him at dawn with their voices, which were like the charming and captivating songs of the Vaitālikas.

original: rātrirgatā matimatāṃ vara muñca śayyāṃ dhātrā dvidhaiva jagato nanu dhūrvibhaktā /
analyzed: rātriḥ gatā matimatām vara muñca śayyām dhātrā dvidhā eva jagataḥ nanu dhūḥ vibhaktā
translated: Night has passed, O best among the wise, leave your bed. Indeed, the burden of the world is borne by the Creator in two ways.

original: yāmekatastava bibharti gururvitandrīryasyā bhavānaparadhuryapadāvalambī // RaghK / //🔽nidrāvaśena bhavatā hyanavekṣyamāṇā paryutsukatvamabalā niśi khaṇḍiteva /
analyzed: yām ekatas tava bibharti guruḥ vitandrīḥ yasyāḥ bhavān apara dhurya pada avalambī  nidrā vaśena bhavatā hi an avekṣyamāṇā paryutsuka tvam abalā niśi khaṇḍitā iva
translated: One part is borne by your father, who is free from sloth, and the other by you, who are the support of the position of the supreme burden-bearer.🔽The powerless one, not being seen by you due to the influence of sleep, is as if broken at night, being full of anxiety.

original: lakṣmīrvinodayati yena digantalambī so 'pi tvadānanarucaṃ vijahāti candraḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: lakṣmīḥ vinodayati yena diś anta lambī saḥ u pi tvad ānana rucam vijahāti candraḥ
translated: Even the moon, which delights her by extending to the ends of the directions, abandons the beauty of your face.

original: tadvalgunā yugapadunmiṣitena tāvat sadyaḥ parasparatulāmadhirohatāṃ dve /
analyzed: tad valgunā yugapad unmiṣitena tāvat sadyas paraspara tulām adhirohatām dve
translated: By that charming thing, which has suddenly arisen together with the other two, let them both ascend the scale at once.

analyzed: praspandamāna paruṣa itara tāram antar cakṣuḥ tava pracalita bhramaram ca padmam
translated: Your eye, with its other pupil trembling, and the lotus with its bee moving.

analyzed: vṛnta ślatham harati puṣpam anokahānām saṃsṛjyate sarasijaiḥ aruṇa aṃśu bhinnaiḥ
translated: The wind, which carries away the flower of the trees loosened from its stalk, is united with the lotuses separated by the reddish rays.

original: svābhāvikaṃ paraguṇena vibhātavātaḥ saugandhyamīpsuriva te mukhamārutasya // RaghK / //
analyzed: svābhāvikam para guṇena vibhāta vātaḥ saugandhyam īpsuḥ iva te mukha mārutasya
translated: As if desiring the fragrance natural to your mouth-wind, it seems to approach your face.

analyzed: tāmra udareṣu patitam druma pallaveṣu nirdhauta hāra gulikā viṣadam hima ambhaḥ
translated: The water, clear as a polished pearl necklace, falling on the tender leaves of trees with copper-colored bellies,

original: saṃlakṣyate daśanacandrikayānuviddhaṃ bimboṣṭhalabdhaparabhāgamiva smitaṃ te // RaghK / //
analyzed: saṃlakṣyate daśana candrikayā anuviddham bimba uṣṭha labdha parabhāgam iva smitam te
translated: appears like a smile, obtained the highest favor from your bimba-like lips, mixed with the moonlight of your teeth.

original: yāvatpratāpanidhirākramate na bhānurahnāya tāvadaruṇena tamo nirastam /
analyzed: yāvat pratāpa nidhiḥ ākramate na bhānuḥ ahne tāvat aruṇena tamaḥ nirastam
translated: As long as the sun, the treasure of heat, does not rise to conquer the day, for that long the darkness is dispelled by the dawn.

original: āyodhanāgrasaratāṃ tvayi vīra yāte kiṃ vā ripūṃstava guruḥ svayamucchinatti // RaghK / //🔽śayyāṃ jahatyubhayapakṣavinītanidrāḥ senāgajā mukharaśṛṅkhalakarṣiṇaste /
analyzed: āyodhana agra sara tām tvayi vīra yāte kim vā ripūn tava guruḥ svayam ucchinatti  śayyām jahati ubhaya pakṣa vinīta nidrāḥ senā gajāḥ mukhara śṛṅkhala karṣiṇaḥ te
translated: When you, O hero, have gone to the forefront of the battle, does your teacher himself destroy your enemies?🔽Your army elephants, leaving sleep conquered on both sides, pulling at their noisy chains,

original: yeṣāṃ vibhānti taruṇāruṇarāgayogādbhinnādrigairikataṭā iva dantakośāḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: yeṣām vibhānti taruṇa aruṇa rāga yogāt bhinna adri gairika taṭāḥ iva dantakośāḥ
translated: whose tusk chambers shine like the slopes of a mountain of red arsenic, tinged with the color of young dawn.

original: dīrgheṣvamī niyamitāḥ paṭamaṇḍapeṣu nidrāṃ vidhūya vanajākṣa vanāyujāste /
analyzed: dīrgheṣu amī niyamitāḥ paṭa maṇḍapeṣu nidrām vidhūya vanaja akṣa vanāyu jāḥ te
translated: In those long tents set up, O forest-born one, those horses, shaking off sleep,

original: vaktroṣmaṇā malinayanti purogatāni lehyāni saindhavaśilāśakalāni vāhāḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: vaktra ūṣmaṇā malinayanti purogatāni lehyāni saindhava śilā śakalāni vāhāḥ
translated: the horses, with the heat of their breath, dirty the lickables placed in front, or the pieces of rock salt.

analyzed: bhavati virala bhaktiḥ mlāna puṣpa upakāraḥ sva kiraṇa pariveśa udbheda śūnyāḥ pradīpāḥ
translated: The devotion of the people is scanty, the flowers offered are faded, and the lamps are devoid of the radiance of their surrounding flames.

original: ayamapi ca giraṃ nastvatprabodhaprayuktāmanuvadati śukaste mañjuvākpañjarasthaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: ayam api ca giram naḥ tvad prabodha prayuktām anuvadati śukaḥ te mañju vāc pañjara sthaḥ
translated: And this parrot of yours, O sweet-voiced one, perched in its cage, repeats the words we spoke to awaken you.

original: iti sa vihṛtanidrastalpamalpetarāṃsaḥ suragaja iva gāṅgaṃ saikataṃ supratīkaḥ /
analyzed: iti sa vihṛta nidraḥ talpam alpa itarāṃsaḥ sura gajaḥ iva gāṅgam saikatam su pratīkaḥ
translated: Thus, his sleep dispelled, he rose from his bed, his shoulders slightly bent, like the well-shaped elephant of the gods rising from the sandy bank of the Ganges.

analyzed: parijana vanitānām pādayoḥ vyāpṛtānām valaya maṇi vidaṣṭa pracchada antam mumoca
translated: He released the hem of his garment, which was held by the jeweled bracelets of the feet of the attendant women who were busy at his feet.

analyzed: atha vidhim avasāyya śāstra dṛṣṭam divasa mukha ucitam añcita akṣi pakṣmā
translated: Then, having performed the rites prescribed by the scriptures, suitable for the beginning of the day, with his eyelashes slightly closed,

analyzed: kuśala viracita anurūpa veśaḥ kṣitipa samājam agāt svayaṃvara stham
translated: he himself went to the assembly of kings, to the svayamvara, dressed in a suitable manner, skillfully arranged.

original: iti raghuvaṃśe mahākāvye pañcamaḥ sargaḥ //🔽sa tatra mañceṣu vimānakalpeṣvākalpasammūrchitarūpaśobhān /
analyzed: iti raghuvaṃśe mahākāvye pañcamaḥ sargaḥ  sa tatra mañceṣu vimāna kalpeṣu ākalpa sammūrchita rūpa śobhān
translated: Thus ends Canto V in the great poem called The Raghu Dynasty, composed by Ashva-atara-yani, the panegyrist of Raghu.🔽There, on the platforms resembling celestial cars, he saw the kings seated on lion-thrones, their beauty enhanced by their incomparable splendor,

analyzed: siṃhāsana sthān nṛpatīn apaśyat yūpān prayastān iva haimavedīn
translated: like sacrificial posts erected, with golden altars.

analyzed: rateḥ gṛhīta anunayena kāmam pratyarpita sva aṅgam iva īśvareṇa
translated: Like the Lord, who, out of love, had taken Kama, the god of love, and returned him to his own body,

original: kākutsthamālokayatāṃ nṛpāṇāṃ mano babhūvendumatīnirāśam // RaghK / //🔽vaidarbhanirdiṣṭamatho kumāraḥ klṝptena sopānapathena mañcam /🔽śilāvibhaṅgairmṛgarājaśāvastuṅgaṃ nagotsaṅgamivāruroha // RaghK / //
analyzed: kākutstham ālokayatām nṛpāṇām manaḥ babhūva indumatī nirāśam  vaidarbha nirdiṣṭam atho kumāraḥ klṝptena sopāna pathena mañcam  śilā vibhaṅgaiḥ mṛgarāja śāvaḥ tuṅgam naga utsaṅgam iva āruroha
translated: The minds of the kings, who were looking at Kakutstha, became hopeless of Indumatī.🔽Then the prince, indicated by the Vidarbha king, ascended the dais by the arranged staircase,🔽like a young lion climbing a lofty mountain peak with its rocky projections.

analyzed: parārdhya varṇa āstaraṇa upapannam āsedivān ratna vat āsanam saḥ
translated: He sat on a jeweled seat covered with an extremely valuable spread,

analyzed: bhūyiṣṭham āsīt upameya kāntiḥ mayūra pṛṣṭha āśrayiṇā guhena
translated: with Guha, whose beauty was often compared to that of the peacock-bannered god, seated on the back of a peacock.

analyzed: tāsu śriyāḥ rāja paramparāsu prabhā viśeṣa udaya durnirīkṣyaḥ
translated: Among those royal dynasties, resplendent with glory, he, whose splendor was difficult to gaze upon,

original: sahasradhātmā vyarucadvibhaktaḥ payomucāṃ paṅktiṣu vidyuteva // RaghK / //
analyzed: sahasradhā ātmā vyarucat vibhaktaḥ payomucām paṅktiṣu vidyutā iva
translated: shone forth in a thousand ways, like lightning in the rows of clouds.

analyzed: teṣām mahārha āsana saṃśrayāṇām udātta nepathya bhṛtām sa madhye
translated: In the midst of them, seated on their magnificent thrones, attired in splendid garments,

original: rarāja dhāmnā raghusūnureva kalpadrumāṇāmiva pārijātaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: rarāja dhāmnā raghu sūnuḥ eva kalpadrumāṇām iva pārijātaḥ
translated: only the son of Raghu shone with his own splendor, like the Pārijāta tree among the wish-fulfilling trees.

analyzed: netra vrajāḥ paura janasya tasmin vihāya sarvān nṛpatīn nipetuḥ
translated: The eyes of the citizens, leaving all the other kings, fell upon him,

original: madotkaṭe recitapuṣpavṛkṣā gandhadvipe vanya iva dvirephāḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: mada utkaṭe recita puṣpa vṛkṣāḥ gandhadvipe vanyaḥ iva dvirephāḥ
translated: Like bees to a wild elephant with ichor oozing from his temples and trees with flowers swaying in the wind.

original: atha stute vandibhiranvayajñaiḥ somārkavaṃśye naradevaloke /🔽sañcārite cāgurusārayonau dhūpe śikhāvāsitaketumāle // RaghK / //🔽puropakaṇṭhopavanāśrayāṇāṃ śikhaṇḍināmuddhatanṛttahetau /
analyzed: atha stute vandibhiḥ anvaya jñaiḥ sa umārka vaṃśye naradeva loke  sañcārite ca aguru sāra yonau dhūpe śikhā vāsita ketumāle  pura upakaṇṭha upavana āśrayāṇām śikhaṇḍinām uddhata nṛtta hetau
translated: Then, when the world of gods and men of the lunar and solar dynasties was praised by bards who knew the genealogies,🔽And when incense from the best of aloe wood was offered, perfuming the crest garlands,🔽The sound of conches being blown all around, the auspicious sound of musical instruments swelling to the ends of the directions,

original: pradhmātaśaṅkhe parito digantāṃstūryasvane mūrchati maṅgalārthe // RaghK / //
analyzed: pradhmāta śaṅkhe paritas diś antān tūrya svane mūrchati maṅgala arthe
translated: The cause of the peacock's excited dancing in the forest groves near the city,

analyzed: manuṣya vāhyam catur anta yānam āsthāya kanyā parivāra śobhi
translated: Awaiting the bride, seated in a four-wheeled carriage drawn by men,

analyzed: viveśa mañca antara rājamārgam patiṃvarā kautuka miśra veśā
translated: She entered the royal road between the pavilions, her beauty enhanced by the retinue of maidens,

analyzed: tasmin vidhāna atiśaye vidhātuḥ kanyā maye netra sahasra lakṣye
translated: In that supreme creation of the Creator, the bride, the target of a million eyes,

analyzed: nipetuḥ antaḥkaraṇaiḥ narendrāḥ dehaiḥ sthitāḥ kevalam āsaneṣu
translated: The kings fell with their hearts, remaining only in their seats with their bodies.

analyzed: tām pratyabhivyakta manorathānām mahīpatīnām praṇaya agra dūtyaḥ
translated: The messengers of love of the kings whose desires were fulfilled by her,

original: pravātaśobhā iva pādapānāṃ śṛṅgāraceṣṭā vividhā babhūvuḥ // RaghK / //🔽kaścitkarābhyāmupagūḍhanālamālolapattrābhihatadvirepham /🔽rajobhirantaḥpariveśaśobhi līlāravindaṃ bhramayāñcakāra // RaghK / //
analyzed: pravāta śobhāḥ iva pādapānām śṛṅgāra ceṣṭāḥ vividhāḥ babhūvuḥ  kaścid karābhyām upagūḍha nālam ālola pattra abhihata dvirepham  rajobhiḥ antar pariveśa śobhi līlā aravindam bhramayāñcakāra
translated: The various amorous gestures of the women were like the beauty of trees in a gentle breeze.🔽One man, holding a lotus with his hands, its stalk grasped, its petals fluttering, and bees buzzing around it,🔽Twirled it playfully, its beauty enhanced by the pollen inside.

analyzed: visrasta maṃsāt aparaḥ vilāsī keyūra koṭi kṣaṇa jāta saṅgam
translated: Another flirtatious man, his upper garment slipping off, its edge momentarily caught by his bracelet,

analyzed: prāvāram utkṣipya yathāpradeśam nināya sācīkṛta cāru vaktraḥ
translated: Pulled it up to the proper place, his beautiful face turned sideways.

original: ākuñcitāgrāṅgulinā tato 'nyaḥ kiñcitsamāvarjitanetraśobhaḥ /🔽ratnāṃśusampṛktanakhaprabheṇa pādena haimaṃ vililekha pīṭham // RaghK / //
analyzed: ākuñcita agra aṅgulinā tatas nyaḥ kiñcid samāvarjita netra śobhaḥ  ratna aṃśu sampṛkta nakha prabheṇa pādena haimam vililekha pīṭham
translated: Then another man, with the tips of his fingers slightly bent, his eyes shining slightly closed,🔽With his foot, its toenails shining with the light of jewels, scratched the golden seat.

original: niveśya vāmaṃ bhujamāsanānte gāḍhāṅgadaṃ pārśvanipīḍanena /🔽kaścidvivṛttatrikabhinnahāraḥ suhṛtsamābhāṣaṇatatparo 'bhūt // RaghK / //
analyzed: niveśya vāmam bhujam āsana ante gāḍha aṅgadam pārśva nipīḍanena  kaścid vivṛtta trika bhinna hāraḥ suhṛd samābhāṣaṇa tatparaḥ bhūt
translated: Placing his left arm on the seat, his heavy bracelet pressing against his side,🔽One man, his necklace broken by the strain, became intent on addressing his friend.

analyzed: vilāsinī vibhrama danta patram āpāṇḍuram ketaka barham anyaḥ
translated: Another man, his white ketaka feather ornament swaying like a coquettish woman's ornament,

original: priyānitambocitasannipātairvipāṭayāmāsa yuvā nakhāgraiḥ // RaghK / //🔽kuśeśayātāmratalena kaścitkareṇa rekhādhvajalāñchanena /
analyzed: priyā nitamba ucita sannipātaiḥ vipāṭayāmāsa yuvā nakha agraiḥ  kuśeśaya ātāmra talena kaścid kareṇa rekhā dhvaja lāñchanena
translated: A young man, with his nails, which were fit to be placed on the hips of his beloved, tore open (the bark of) a tree.🔽Someone, with a hand having the palm red like a lotus, marked with the lines of a flag,

analyzed: dīpra aṅgulīya prabhayā anuviddhān udārayāmāsa sa līlam akṣān
translated: playfully rolled the dice, illuminated by the bright light of the ring on his finger.

analyzed: kaścid yathābhāgam avasthite sva sanniveśa vyatilaṅghinī iva
translated: Someone, though seated in his proper place, as if transgressing his own position,

analyzed: vajra aṃśu garbha aṅguli randhram ekam vyāpārayāmāsa karam kirīṭe
translated: placed his hand, with the fingers of which the rays of a diamond were enclosed, on his diadem.

analyzed: tatas nṛpāṇām śruta vṛtta vaṃśā puṃvat pragalbhā pratihāra rakṣī
translated: Then the female doorkeeper, who was bold like a man, having heard the genealogies of the kings,

analyzed: prāc sannikarṣam magadha īśvarasya nītvā kumārīm avadat sunandā
translated: having brought the maiden near the lord of Magadha, Sunanda spoke.

original: asau śaraṇyaḥ śaraṇotsukānāmagādhasattvo magadhapratiṣṭhaḥ /🔽rājā prajārañjanalabdhavarṇaḥ parantapo nāma yathārthanāmā // RaghK / //
analyzed: asau śaraṇyaḥ śaraṇa utsukānām agādha sattvaḥ magadha pratiṣṭhaḥ  rājā prajā rañjana labdha varṇaḥ parantapaḥ nāma yathārtha nāmā
translated: This is the refuge of those eager for protection, of deep courage, established in Magadha,🔽the king who has obtained fame by delighting his subjects, the conqueror of enemies, his name true to its meaning.

original: kāmaṃ nṛpāḥ santi sahasrasaṅkhyā rājanvatīmāhuranena pṛthvīm /
analyzed: kāmam nṛpāḥ santi sahasra saṅkhyāḥ rājanvatīm āhuḥ anena pṛthvīm
translated: There are indeed thousands of kings, but he alone is the king, thus the earth, possessing kings, is said to belong to him.

analyzed: nakṣatra tārā graha saṅkulā api jyotiṣmatī candramasā eva rātriḥ
translated: The night, though crowded with stars, planets, and constellations, is truly luminous only with the moon.

original: kriyāprabandhādayamadhvarāṇāmajasramāhūtasahasranetraḥ /🔽śacyāściraṃ pāṇḍukapolalambānmandāraśūnyānalakāṃścakāra // RaghK / //🔽anena cedicchasi gṛhyamāṇaṃ pāṇiṃ vareṇyena kuru praveśe /
analyzed: kriyā prabandhāt ayam adhvarāṇām ajasram āhūta sahasranetraḥ  śacyāḥ ciram pāṇḍu kapola lambān mandāra śūnyān alakān cakāra  anena ced icchasi gṛhyamāṇam pāṇim vareṇyena kuru praveśe
translated: By the continuous performance of sacrifices, this thousand-eyed one (Indra) is constantly invited.🔽And the jasmine flowers on the cheeks of Sachi, hanging down for a long time, he made them devoid of jasmine flowers.

analyzed: prāsāda vātāyana saṃśrayāṇām netra utsavam puṣpapura aṅganānām
translated: If you desire to take this hand, which is being seized by the most excellent one, make it enter the eyes of the women of Pushpapura, who are staying in the windows of the palace.

analyzed: evam tayā ukte tam avekṣya kiñcid visraṃsi dūrvā aṅka madhūka mālā
translated: When she said this, she saw him, with the garland of Madhuka flowers mixed with Durva grass slightly slipping down.

analyzed: ṛju praṇāma kriyayā eva tanvī pratyādideśa enam abhāṣamāṇā
translated: The slender one, without speaking, rejected him only by the act of bowing straight.

original: tāṃ sātha vetragrahaṇe niyuktā rājāntaraṃ rājasutāṃ nināya /
analyzed: tām sā atha vetra grahaṇe niyuktā rāja antaram rāja sutām nināya
translated: Then she, appointed to hold the cane, took the princess to another king.

analyzed: samīraṇa utthā iva taraṅga lekhā padma antaram mānasa rājahaṃsīm
translated: Like a wave rising from the wind, the royal swan of Manas took her to another lotus.

analyzed: jagāda ca enām ayam aṅganāthaḥ sura aṅganā prārthita yauvana śrīḥ
translated: And she said to her, This lord of women, whose youth and beauty are sought by celestial women,

original: vinītabhāgaḥ kila sūtrakārairaindraṃ padaṃ bhūmigato 'pi bhuṅkte // RaghK / //
analyzed: vinīta bhāgaḥ kila sūtrakāraiḥ aindram padam bhūmi gataḥ bhuṅkte
translated: The author of the sutras, having humbly accepted his share, enjoys even from the earth the position of Indra.

analyzed: anena paryāsayatā aśru bindūn muktāphala sthūlatamān staneṣu  pratyarpitāḥ śatru vilāsinīnām ākṣepa sūtreṇa vinā eva hārāḥ
translated: By this one, wiping away the large pearl-like tears on their breasts,🔽the necklaces of the rival beauties are returned without the thread of reproach.

analyzed: nisarga bhinna āspadam eka saṃstham asmin dvayam śrīḥ ca sarasvatī ca
translated: In this one, the two, Lakshmi and Saraswati, though born in different abodes, are united.

original: kāntyā girā sūnṛtayā ca yogyā tvameva kalyāṇi tayostṛtīyā // RaghK / //
analyzed: kāntyā girā sūnṛtayā ca yogyā tvam eva kalyāṇi tayoḥ tṛtīyā
translated: O fortunate one, you are the third, worthy by your beauty, speech, and truthfulness.

analyzed: atha aṅgarājāt avatārya cakṣuḥ yātā iti janyān avadat kumārī
translated: Then, turning her eyes away from the king of Anga, the maiden said to the people,

original: nāsau na kāmyo na ca veda samyag draṣṭuṃ na sā bhinnarucirhi lokaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: na asau na kāmyaḥ na ca veda samyak draṣṭum na sā bhinna ruciḥ hi lokaḥ
translated: He is not unlovely, nor does the world lack the right discernment to see him; it is only that the world has a different taste.

original: tataḥ paraṃ duṣprasahaṃ pareṣāṃ nṛpaṃ niyuktā pratihārabhūmau /
analyzed: tatas param duṣprasaham pareṣām nṛpam niyuktā pratihāra bhūmau
translated: Then, in the reception hall, she pointed out to the king, who was difficult for others to approach,

analyzed: nidarśayāmāsa viśeṣa kāntam indum nava utthānam iva indumatyāḥ
translated: the moon, especially lovely, as if newly risen for Indumati.

analyzed: avantināthaḥ yam udagra bāhuḥ viśāla vakṣāḥ tanu vṛtta madhyaḥ
translated: This king of Avanti, with upraised arms, broad chest, and slender waist,

original: āropya cakrabhramamuṣṇatejāstvaṣṭreva yantrollikhito vibhāti // RaghK / //🔽asya prayāṇeṣu samagraśakteragresarairvājibhiruddhatāni /

translated: And, mounted on it, he appears as if drawn in a machine by Tvashtri, with the whirling discus, having a fiery splendour.🔽When this king, whose power is complete, goes out, the dust raised by the horses that precede him,

original: kurvanti sāmantaśikhāmaṇīṇāṃ prabhāprarohāstamayaṃ rajāṃsi // RaghK / //🔽asau mahākālaniketanasya candrārdhamaulernivasannadūre /
analyzed: kurvanti sāmanta śikhāmaṇīṇām prabhā praroha astamayam rajāṃsi  asau mahākāla niketanasya candra ardha mauleḥ nivasan adūre
translated: obscures the rays of the crest-jewels of the feudatory princes.🔽He, dwelling not far from the abode of the moon-crested Shiva,

original: divāpi jālāntaracandrikāṇāṃ nārīsakhaḥ sparśasukhāni bhuṅkte // RaghK / //
analyzed: divā api jāla antara candrikāṇām nārī sakhaḥ sparśa sukhāni bhuṅkte
translated: even by day, with his lady-friends, enjoys the pleasure of touch from the moonbeams through the windows.

original: anena yūnā saha pārthivena rambhoru kaccinmanaso ruciste /
analyzed: anena yūnā saha pārthivena rambhā ūru kaccit manasaḥ ruciḥ te
translated: O slender-thighed one, do you take delight in your mind with this young king,

analyzed: siprā taraṅga anila kampitāsu vihartum udyāna paramparāsu
translated: to sport in the series of gardens, shaken by the breeze from the Taranga lake,

analyzed: tasmin api dyotana rūpa bimbe pratāpa saṃśoṣita śatru paṅke
translated: In that mirror of the form of illumination, with the mud of enemies dried up by his valour,

original: babandha sā nottamasaukumāryā kumudvatī bhānumatīva bhāvam // RaghK / //
analyzed: babandha sā nā uttama saukumāryā kumudvatī bhānumatī iva bhāvam
translated: she did not bind her affection, due to her extreme delicacy, like a white lily to the sun.

analyzed: tām agratas tāmarasa antara ābhām anūpa rājasya guṇaiḥ anūnām
translated: That one, whose eyes are like lotuses, who is not inferior in qualities to the king of the marshy region,

analyzed: vidhāya sṛṣṭim lalitām vidhātuḥ jagāda bhūyas su nasām sunandā
translated: Having thus created the beautiful world, the Creator again spoke to Sunanda, the daughter of the mountain, who had a beautiful nose.

analyzed: saṅgrāma nirvṛtta sahasra bāhuḥ aṣṭādaśa dvīpa nikhāta yūpaḥ
translated: He, whose arms were as many as the number of battles fought, who had sacrificial posts planted in the eighteen islands,

original: ananyasādhāraṇarājaśabdo babhūva yogī kila kārtavīryaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: an anya sādhāraṇa rāja śabdaḥ babhūva yogī kila kārtavīryaḥ
translated: and who was called the king without any equal, was said to be a yogi, King Kartavirya.

analyzed: akārya cintā sama kālam eva prādurbhavan cāpa dharaḥ purastāt
translated: As soon as the thought of doing a wrong deed arose, he appeared in front with a bow in his hand,

original: antaḥśarīreṣvapi yaḥ prajānāṃ pratyādideśāvinayaṃ vinetā // RaghK / //
analyzed: antar śarīreṣu api yaḥ prajānām pratyādideśa a vinayam vinetā
translated: and that chastiser of the unrighteous forbade indiscipline even in the inner hearts of the people.

analyzed: jyā bandha niḥspanda bhujena yasya viniḥśvasat vaktra parampareṇa
translated: By him, with his arms motionless due to the binding of the bowstring, with a series of faces sighing,

analyzed: kārā gṛhe nirjita vāsavena daśānanena uṣita mā prasādāt
translated: the ten-headed Ravana, having conquered Indra, dwelt in the prison-house with his favor.

analyzed: tasya anvaye bhūpatiḥ eṣa jātaḥ pradīpaḥ iti āgama vṛddha sevī
translated: In his lineage, this king was born, named Dipti, who was served by the aged people,

original: yena śriyaḥ saṃśrayadoṣarūḍhaṃ svabhāvaloletyayaśaḥ pramṛṣṭam // RaghK / //
analyzed: yena śriyaḥ saṃśraya doṣa rūḍham svabhāva lola iti ayaśaḥ pramṛṣṭam
translated: by whom the infamy that had arisen due to the fault of being the refuge of Lakshmi, which was naturally fickle, was wiped away.

analyzed: āyodhane kṛṣṇa gatim sahāyam avāpya yaḥ kṣatriya kālarātrim
translated: He, who having obtained Krishna as his ally in the battle, made the night of destruction for the Kshatriyas,

original: dhārāṃ śitāṃ rāmaparaśvadhasya sambhāvayatyutpalapattrasārām // RaghK / //🔽asyāṅkalakṣmīrbhava dīrghabāhormāhiṣmatīvapranitambakāñcīm /
analyzed: dhārām śitām rāma paraśvadhasya sambhāvayati utpala pattra sārām  asya aṅka lakṣmīḥ bhava dīrgha bāhoḥ māhiṣmatī vapra nitamba kāñcīm
translated: And who considers the sharp edge of Rama's battle-axe to be as tender as a lotus petal.🔽O Long-armed One, be the ornament of the hips of the city of Mahishmati, which is the Lakshmi of this earth.

original: prāsādajālairjalaveṇiramyāṃ revāṃ yadi prekṣitumasti kāmaḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: prāsāda jālaiḥ jala veṇi ramyām revām yadi prekṣitum asti kāmaḥ
translated: If you have a desire to see the river Narmada, which is beautiful with its water-filled bamboos and adorned with palaces,

analyzed: tasyāḥ prakāma priya darśanaḥ u pi na sa kṣitīśaḥ rucaye babhūva
translated: That king, though pleasing to look at, was not to her liking.

analyzed: śarad pramṛṣṭa ambudhara uparāgaḥ śaśī iva paryāpta kalaḥ nalinyāḥ
translated: Like the moon, which is sufficient for the lotus-pond, but is devoid of the beauty of the autumn clouds.

analyzed: sā śūrasena adhipatim suṣeṇam uddiśya deśa antara gīta kīrtim
translated: That maiden, whose fame was sung in other countries,

analyzed: ācāra śuddha ubhaya vaṃśa dīpam śuddha anta rakṣyā jagade kumārī
translated: The lamp of two pure royal lineages, the daughter of the king of Shurasenas,

original: nīpānvayaḥ pārthiva eṣa yajvā guṇairyamāśritya paraspareṇa /
analyzed: nīpa anvayaḥ pārthivaḥ eṣa yajvā guṇaiḥ yam āśritya paraspareṇa
translated: This king of the Nipu lineage, who performed sacrifices, by relying on each other's qualities,

original: naisargiko 'pyutsasṛje virodhaḥ siddhāśramaṃ śāntamivaitya sattvaiḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: naisargikaḥ pi utsasṛje virodhaḥ siddhāśramam śāntam iva etya sattvaiḥ
translated: Though natural, gave up enmity, like the Siddha hermitage, which is shunned by violent beings.🔽In whose body, the beauty that delights the eyes,

analyzed: yasya ātma dehe nayana abhirāmā kāntiḥ himāṃśoḥ iva sanniviṣṭā
translated: Is like the moon settled.

analyzed: harmya agra saṃrūḍha tṛṇa aṅkureṣu tejaḥ viṣahyam ripu mandireṣu
translated: The splendour of the enemy's palaces, unable to bear the heat, took refuge in the grass-shoots growing on the tops of the mansions.

analyzed: yasya avarodha stana candanānām prakṣālanāt vāri vihāra kāle
translated: Whose breasts, washed at the time of bathing in the water, are the abode of the sandal paste of the moon.

analyzed: kalinda kanyā mathurā gatā api gaṅgā ūrmi sampṛkta jalā iva bhāti
translated: The daughter of Kaliṅga, though come to Mathurā, shines as if her water is mixed with the waves of the Ganges.

original: trātena tārkṣyātkila kāliyena maṇiṃ visṛṣṭaṃ yamunaukasā yaḥ /
analyzed: trātena tārkṣyāt kila kāliyena maṇim visṛṣṭam yamunaukasā yaḥ
translated: By whom, the lord of the Yamunā, a jewel was given, it is said, to Kāliya, who was saved from Garuḍa.

original: vakṣaḥsthalavyāpirucaṃ dadhānaḥ sakaustubhaṃ hrepayatīva kṛṣṇam // RaghK / //🔽sambhāvya bhartāramamuṃ yuvānaṃ mṛdupravālottarapuṣpaśayye /
analyzed: vakṣaḥsthala vyāpi rucam dadhānaḥ sa kaustubham hrepayati iva kṛṣṇam  sambhāvya bhartāram amum yuvānam mṛdu pravāla uttara puṣpa śayye
translated: Wearing a lustre spreading over the chest, he as if puts to shame Kṛṣṇa, who has the Kaustubha jewel.

analyzed: vṛndāvane caitrarathāt anūne nirviśyatām sundari yauvana śrīḥ
translated: Having honoured this young husband, O beautiful lady, let the glory of youth be enjoyed in Vṛndāvana, which is not inferior to Caitraratha, on a bed of tender sprouts and flowers.

analyzed: adhyāsya ca ambhaḥ pṛṣata ukṣitāni śaileya naddhāni śilā talāni
translated: And having occupied the rocky surfaces covered with moss and bound with moss,

analyzed: kalāpinām prāvṛṣi paśya nṛttam kāntāsu govardhana kandarāsu
translated: see the dance of the peacocks in the rainy season in the beloved caves of Govardhana.

analyzed: nṛpam tam āvarta manojña nābhiḥ sā vyatyagāt anya vadhūḥ bhavitrī
translated: That other woman, whose navel is charming when turned, passed by that king, who was destined to be killed by another.

analyzed: mahīdharam mārga vaśāt upetam srotaḥ vahā sāgara gāminī iva
translated: like a river flowing towards the ocean, following the path of a mountain.

analyzed: athā aṅgada śliṣṭa bhujam bhujiṣyā hemāṅgadam nāma kaliṅga nātham
translated: Then she approached the lord of Kalinga, named Hemaṅgada, whose arms were embraced by Aṅgada,

analyzed: āseduṣī sā ādita śatru pakṣam bālām abāla indu mukhīm babhāṣe
translated: and spoke to the youthful one, whose face was like the full moon, who had destroyed the wings of his enemies.

original: asau mahendrādrisamānasāraḥ patirmahendrasya mahodadheśca /🔽yasya kṣaratsainyagajacchalena yātrāsu yātīva puro mahendraḥ // RaghK / //
analyzed: asau mahendra adri samāna sāraḥ patiḥ mahendrasya mahodadheḥ ca  yasya kṣarat sainya gaja chalena yātrāsu yāti iva puras mahā indraḥ
translated: He, whose essence is equal to the great Indra mountain, is the lord of Mahendra and the great ocean.🔽In whose expeditions, the great Indra seems to go in front, by the trick of the trumpeting of his army elephants.

original: jyāghātalekhe subhujo bhujābhyāṃ bibharti yaścāpabhṛtāṃ purogaḥ /
analyzed: jyā ghāta lekhe su bhujaḥ bhujābhyām bibharti yaḥ cāpa bhṛtām purogaḥ
translated: And he, who with his well-formed arms, bears the two lines of the bow-string marks, and is the foremost of bowmen,

analyzed: ripu śriyaḥ sāñjana vāṣpa seke vandīkṛtāyāḥ iva paddhatī dve
translated: as if they were the two lines of the wealth of his enemies, made captive with reddened eyes and tears.

analyzed: yam ātmanaḥ sadmani saudha jālaiḥ ālokya velā taṭa pūga mālaḥ
translated: He, who, in his abode, by the rows of windows in the palace, sees the betel-nut trees on the shore of the ocean,

analyzed: mandra dhvanityā ajita yāma tūryaḥ prabodhayati arṇave eva suptam
translated: wakes up the sleeping ocean itself with the sweet sound of his conch, surpassing the music of the Yamas.

analyzed: anena sārdham vihara amburāśeḥ tīreṣu tālī vana marmareṣu
translated: With him, O ocean, sport on the shores of the ocean, in the groves of palm trees,

analyzed: apākṛta sveda lavāḥ marudbhiḥ dvīpa antara ānīta lavaṅga puṣpaiḥ  prabodhitā api ākṛti lobhanīyā vidarbha rāja avarajā tayā evam
translated: The drops of sweat on her body were removed by the winds bringing with them the Lavanga flowers from other islands.🔽Thus addressed, the daughter of the king of Vidarbha, though awakened, was still reluctant to leave, being attracted by his form.

original: tasmādapāvartata pauruṣeṇa nīteva lakṣmīḥ pratikūladaivāt // RaghK / //
analyzed: tasmāt apāvartata pauruṣeṇa nītā iva lakṣmīḥ pratikūla daivāt
translated: She turned away from him with her own strength, as if Lakshmi (the goddess of wealth) turned away from an unlucky person.

analyzed: atha unnasam nāgapurasya nātham dauvārikī deva sarūpam etya
translated: Then the doorkeeper, who was like a goddess, approached the lord of Nagapura, who was tall,

original: itaścakorākṣi vilokayeti nāgāṅganābhāṃ nijagāda bhojyām // RaghK / //
analyzed: itas cakora akṣi vilokaya iti nāga aṅganā ābhām nijagāda bhojyām
translated: and said to the daughter of the Naga king, Look here, O Chakora-eyed one!

analyzed: pāṇḍyaḥ yad aṃsa arpita lamba hāraḥ klṝpta aṅgarāgaḥ haricandanena
translated: This Pandya king, with his long necklace hanging down to his hips, his body anointed with Haricandana paste,

original: ābhāti bālātaparaktasānuḥ sanirjharodgāra ivādrirājaḥ // RaghK / //🔽vindhyasya saṃstambhayitā mahādrerniḥśeṣapītojjhitasindhunāthaḥ /
analyzed: ābhāti bāla ātapa rakta sānuḥ sa nirjhara udgāraḥ iva adrirājaḥ  vindhyasya saṃstambhayitā mahā adreḥ niḥśeṣa pīta ujjhita sindhu nāthaḥ
translated: looks like the king of mountains with its peaks reddened by the morning sun, with its waterfalls flowing down.🔽Agastya, who arrested the growth of the great mountain Vindhya, who drank up the entire ocean and left it dry,

analyzed: prītyā aśvamedha avabhṛtha ārdra mūrteḥ sausnātikaḥ yasya bhavati agastyaḥ
translated: whose body is wet with the concluding bath of the horse sacrifice, will be his officiating priest.

analyzed: astram harāt āptavatā durāpam yena indra loka avajayāya dṛptaḥ
translated: By him, who proudly obtained the invincible weapon from Shiva for the conquest of Indra's world,

original: purā janasthānavimardaśaṅkī sandhāya laṅkādhipatiḥ pratasthe // RaghK / //🔽anena pāṇau vidhivadgṛhīte mahākulīnena mahīva gurvī /

translated: Fearing a conflict with Janasthana, the lord of Lanka made peace and departed.🔽When this prince of great lineage has taken your hand in due form, you will be as heavy to him as the earth is to the mountains.

original: ratnānuviddhārṇavamekhalāyā diśaḥ sapatnī bhava dakṣiṇasyāḥ // RaghK / //🔽tāmbūlavallīpariṇaddhapūgāsvailālatāliṅgitacandanāsu /
